text:
Hi everyone. We just got back from our
family vacation. We flew to Bermuda, and

we had to leave our car out in a parking
lot for several days. It got kind of

dirty, so it needs to be washed. Where we
live, we have two choices: We can drive

our car to a local car wash and pay
about $10. It can be a little less if you

just want to wash the car. If you want to
polish the wheels, wax your car to a

shine, and also wash the undercarriage,
you'll pay about fifteen dollars or more.

The other choice is to wash the car in
your driveway. It's summertime, so it's

the more affordable option. So I'm going
to pull the car out of the garage and

get started. I also want to see if
there's anyone around to help. By the way,

you'll hear American English speakers
use two different pronunciations of this

word. I use both. I don't know if growing
up in western Pennsylvania was a factor.

Perhaps. And, of course, the British have
their own pronunciation, a third

pronunciation of this word. You can use
online tools like YouGlish and Forvo

to hear different models. If you'd like,
try saying it both ways: garage (zh)/ garage (j)

Since we're talking about washing the
car, you may be curious about the

differences between these words: wash,
clean, polish, and wax. Washing is with

soap and water. I'm going to wash the car.
I'm going to wash the exterior of the car.

Cleaning can just be making things
neat and tidy. Later I'm going to clean

the seats. I'm going to vacuum them to
pick up crumbs of food and dog fur.

Polishing and waxing are similar. We can
polish the wheels and the hubcaps. We rub

them until they shine. People also polish
things like good leather shoes and

expensive silverware. Waxing is with a
special cleaner. We can wax the hood and

the sides of the car until they shine.
Waxing also protects the paint. So what

do I need to wash the car? I could use my
bare hands, but I don't want harsh

chemicals to touch my skin. I'm very
sensitive, so I'll wear rubber gloves.

I'll also need a bucket of clean water, a
garden hose, some special soap, a sponge,

some old towels, and wax that I'll spray
on and wipe off.

So today I mostly want to make sure the
exterior is clean. The inside of the car

is already pretty clean because my kids
and I did a thorough job last month. We
wiped down the seats. We vacuumed. We took out the floor mats and washed them.

But I still think I need to clean the
windows today.
How about a quick game of opposites? Okay? I'll say a word, and you give me the
antonym. Ready? Exterior - interior. Clean -

dirty. Shiny - dull. Wet - dry.
How about neat and tidy?

Maybe messy, untidy, sloppy. Harsh, as in
harsh chemicals.

How about gentle, as in gentle on the
skin? Now let's switch to synonyms, words

with similar meanings. Interior - inside.
Exterior - outside. Shiny -

How about bright? What's another way to
say, "My arm hurts from all the rubbing
and wiping"? How about, "My arm is sore from all the rubbing and wiping"?

Is there a difference between rubbing
and wiping? I'd say yes. Rubbing is with

effort. We press or push. We can rub back
and forth. We can rub in circles. When
people have headaches, they sometimes rub their temples. We wipe things to make

them clean and dry. We can wipe off dirt.
We can wipe dishes after washing them.
We can wipe our forehead if we get sweaty.

Well, I think I'm mostly done. I've washed
the car from top to bottom. I've rinsed

off all the soap, I've wiped the car dry,
and I've waxed it to a shine. What do you think?

Have you ever washed a car or helped
someone to wash a car? If you own a car,

how long does it take you to wash it and
how often do you wash your car? Do you

have any tips? If you don't own a car,
maybe you can tell me what other work

takes you outside the house in warm
weather. Well, that's all for now. I hope

you found this useful and interesting.
Feel free to share the lesson with

others learning English. Please like the
video and subscribe to my channel.

As always, thanks for watching and happy
studies! Become a member of my learning

community. Click the JOIN button to
become a member of my YouTube channel,

English with Jennifer. You'll get a
special badge, bonus posts, on-screen

credit, and a monthly live stream. Note
that YouTube channel memberships are not

available in every country at this time.
I'd like to say a very special thank you

to the current members of my channel.
Hopefully, more of you will join us for

the next live stream. Follow me and gain
more practice on Facebook and Twitter.
I also have new videos on Instagram. If you haven't already, subscribe to my channel

so you get notification of every new
video I upload to YouTube.
